EPI200.name: A Multi-disciplinary Approach to Problems in Global Public Health and Epidemiology
EPI200.description: Overview of global health and the role of epidemiology in studying health problems from a multi-disciplinary perspective.
EPI200.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Global Publc Health and Epidemiology Minor or approval of department.

EPI280.name: Applied Analytic Methods in Health Studies I
EPI280.description: Introduction to conceptual and analytical methods used in Public Health and Epidemiology. Programming, statistical techniques, and interpretation of health data.
EPI280.prerequisite: (EPI 200) and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 224 or STT 231 or STT 315 or STT 351 or STT 421)
EPI280.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Global Public Health and Epidemiology Minor or approval of department.

EPI289.name: Independent Study
EPI289.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EPI289.description: Faculty supervised, introductory, planned learning for an individual student in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

EPI290.name: History of Scientific Reasoning and Critical Thinking in Global Public Health and Epidemiology
EPI290.description: Introduction to the historical development of public health and epidemiology and how social and scientific contexts shape scientific theories of disease distribution.
EPI290.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Global Public Health and Epidemiology Specialization.

EPI380.name: Applied Analytic Methods in Health Studies II
EPI380.description: Topics in conceptual and analytical methods used in Public Health and Epidemiology. Continuation of EPI 280.
EPI380.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Global Public Health and Epidemiology Minor or approval of department.

EPI390.name: Disease in Society: Introduction to Epidemiology and Public Health
EPI390.description: Human epidemiology and population health issues facing contemporary society. Developed and less-developed settings. Health-related information in the mass media and scholarly publications.

EPI465.name: Bayesian Statistical Methods
EPI465.description: Probability, belief, and exchangeability. Objective, subjective, and empirical Bayes approaches. Applications to one-parameter models, linear regression models, and multivariate normal models. Hierarchical modeling. Computational methods.

EPI489.name: Independent Study
EPI489.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EPI489.description: Faculty supervised, intermediate-level, planned learning for an individual student in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

EPI490.name: Advanced Topics/Methods in Global Public Health and Epidemiology
EPI490.description: Conceptual and analytical methods used in public health and epidemiology.
EPI490.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Global Public Health and Epidemiology Specialization.

EPI495.name: Epidemiology and Behavioral Health in Society
EPI495.description: Introduction to epidemiology as applied to behavioral health issues in contemporary society. Life-span developmental perspective from preterm births to late life Alzheimer's disease and the dementias.
EPI495.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

EPI546.name: Information Management: Fundamentals of Epidemiology and Biostatistics
EPI546.description: Introduction to accessing, analyzing, and applying information to patients and to populations. Offered first ten weeks of the semester.
EPI546.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

EPI547.name: Information Management: Applications of Epidemiology and Biostats
EPI547.description: Basic competency in accessing, analyzing, and applying information to patients and populations. Offered first half of semester.
EPI547.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Human Medicine or approval of department.

EPI805.name: Readings in the Historical Roots of Epidemiological Thought
EPI805.description: Historical evolution of models of disease causation and population perspectives on disease.
EPI805.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI808.name: Biostatistics I
EPI808.description: Applications of probability and statistics in the applied health sciences. Probability distributions, estimation and tests for one-, two-, and paired samples, linear regression, correlation, and ANOVA. Use of statistical software. Critical appraisal of statistical methods in the biomedical literature.
EPI808.restrictions: Open to master's students or doctoral students in the Epidemiology major or approval of department.

EPI808B.name: Advanced Biostatistics
EPI808B.description: Fundamental theory of probability and statistical inference related to the practice of public health. Discrete and continuous random variables, sampling distributions, parametric point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing, maximum likelihood estimates, methods of constructing test and estimation procedures. Sample size, power, and efficiency.
EPI808B.prerequisite: EPI 810 or concurrently or approval of department
EPI808B.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Biostatistics Major or in the Epidemiology Major or approval of department.

EPI809.name: Biostatistics II
EPI809.description: Analysis of categorical data in epidemiologic studies. Contingency tables and logistic regression.
EPI809.restrictions: Open to master's students or doctoral students in the Epidemiology major or approval of department.

EPI810.name: Introductory Epidemiology
EPI810.description: Disease from a population perspective as the interaction of host, agent, and environment. Case definition, measuring frequency of disease, mortality and morbidity data, and major study designs. Offered first half of semester.
EPI810.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI812.name: Causal Inference in Epidemiology
EPI812.description: Causality in epidemiology. Application of theoretical concepts to the design, analysis, and assessment of epidemiologic research.
EPI812.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI815.name: Epidemiology of Cardiovascular Disease
EPI815.description: Survey of methodologies used in epidemiologic studies of cardiovascular diseases. Review of evidence of genetic, environmental, and behavioral causes of cardiovascular disease.
EPI815.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI816.name: Perinatal Epidemiology
EPI816.description: Epidemiology of adverse health states in pregnancy and the puerperium. Impact of these health states on subsequent child development.
EPI816.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI817.name: Epidemiology of Communicable Diseases
EPI817.description: Application of principles of epidemiology to research in communicable diseases relevant to public health in the U.S. and other countries.
EPI817.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI819.name: Spatial Epidemiology and Medical Geography
EPI819.description: Concepts, techniques, and utilization of spatio-epidemiologic analyses for human health.
EPI819.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or in the Department of Geography or approval of department.

EPI823.name: Cancer Epidemiology
EPI823.description: Basic principles of carcinogenesis. Major etiologic factors, types of malignancies, and biomarkers for susceptibility and exposure. Prevention and early detection of cancer.
EPI823.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI826.name: Research Methods in Epidemiology
EPI826.description: Analyses of epidemiologic and clinical data applying statistical methods, based on logistic and survival models, using standard software.
EPI826.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI826B.name: Categorical Data Analysis
EPI826B.description: Applications to real data from clinical and epidemiologic studies of categorical outcomes, distributions for categorical responses and contingency tables, logistic regression and related logit models for binary and multicategory response variables, repeated and clustered categorical data, generalized linear mixed models.
EPI826B.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Biostatistics Major or in the Epidemiology Major or approval of department.

EPI828.name: Seminar in Responsible Conduct of Research
EPI828.description: Ethical and regulatory issues in the responsible conduct of epidemiology research. Topics include informed consent; scientific misconduct; human subjects protection; responsible data management including electronic medical records, biological samples and genetic data; HIPAA compliance; and other current issues of scientific integrity.

EPI829.name: Design and Conduct of Epidemiological Studies and Clinical Trials
EPI829.description: Applied analytical methods in experimental design. Assessment of health and disease status of animal and human populations. Risk assessment and interpretation of clinical trials.

EPI835.name: Neuroepidemiology
EPI835.description: Epidemiology of neurologic and neuropsychiatric disorders with emphases on neurodegenerative disorders (e.g., Alzheimer's disease).
EPI835.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI836.name: Practicum in Epidemiological Methods
EPI836.description: Data management, analysis, interpretation and presentations using public data sets.
EPI836.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI840.name: Clinical Epidemiology for Healthcare Practice
EPI840.description: Introduction to clinical epidemiology and evidence-based medicine for clinical practitioners and other healthcare professionals.

EPI847.name: Analysis of Survival Data
EPI847.description: Analysis of lifetime data. Estimation of survival functions for parametric and nonparametric models. Censored data. The Cox proportional hazards model. Accelerated failure time models. Frailty models. Use of statistical software packages.

EPI851.name: SAS Programming I: Essentials
EPI851.description: A programming approach to plan and write simple SAS programs to solve common data management and data analysis problems.
EPI851.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI852.name: SAS Programming II: Data Management and Analysis
EPI852.description: A programming approach to plan and write SAS programs to solve common data management and data analysis problems.
EPI852.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI853B.name: Statistical Computing
EPI853B.description: Statistical computation and algorithms using programming languages, SAS/IML, R and/or Stata, Newton-Raphson method, Monte Carlo simulation of probability distributions, bootstrap, statistical graphics.
EPI853B.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Biostatistics Major or in the Epidemiology Major or approval of department.

EPI855.name: Biostatistical Modeling in Genomic Data Analysis
EPI855.description: Introduction to fundamental principles and modeling of genomic /genetic data and computational techniques
EPI855.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI856.name: Statistical Consulting in Public Health
EPI856.description: Critical appraisal of applied epidemiological studies, use of real applications to solve design and data analysis problem, and communication of findings to public health researchers, oral/written reports on intermediate and final results of case studies
EPI856.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI858.name: Clinical Trials
EPI858.description: Statistical methods for design and analysis of clinical trials and epidemiological studies. Phase I, II, and III clinical trials. Principle of Intention-to-Treat, effects of non-compliance, drop-outs. Interim monitoring of clinical trials and data safety monitoring boards. Meta-analysis. Crossover designs. Sample size and power in clinical trials. Sequential designs.
EPI858.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI860.name: Advanced Inference for Biostatistics
EPI860.description: Statistical inference problems with biomedical applications.
EPI860.prerequisite: STT 861 and (STT 862 or concurrently) or approval of department
EPI860.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI880.name: Select Topics in Biostatistics
EPI880.description: Select topics in biostatistics including global disease distribution and estimation, causal inference, Bayesian methods in health services research.
EPI880.prerequisite: (EPI 808B) or (EPI 808 and EPI 809) or (PHM 830 or STT 464)
EPI880.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI889.name: Applied Epidemiologic Methods for Public Health Practitioners
EPI889.description: Identification and conceptualization of public health problems. Generation of testable hypotheses and appropriate data sets. Interpretation of appropriate measures of associations. Evaluation of validity and generalizability of results and ethical issues surrounding the use of humans in epidemiological research. Real case studies are used to analyze study design including the role of chance, bias, misclassification, effect measure modification, interaction, and missing data.
EPI889.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

EPI890.name: Independent Study in Epidemiology and Biostatistics
EPI890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EPI890.description: Independent study in areas relevant to epidemiology and biostatistics.
EPI890.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics. Approval of department.

EPI899.name: Master's Thesis Research
EPI899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EPI899.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics. Approval of department.

EPI910.name: Themes in Contemporary Epidemiology
EPI910.description: Discussion and critique of important contemporary themes in epidemiology as reflected in current publications in the field.
EPI910.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Epidemiology major.

EPI919.name: COVID-19 Epidemiology and Public Health (Interim New)
EPI919.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EPI919.description: Application of epidemiologic and public health principles to COVID-19.
EPI919.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI920.name: Advanced Methods in Epidemiology and Applied Statistics
EPI920.description: Pattern recognition and cluster analysis, longitudinal data analysis, path analysis, repeated measures and time-series analysis.
EPI920.prerequisite: (EPI 826B or concurrently) or EPI 826 or approval of department
EPI920.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI935.name: Research Seminar
EPI935.description: Conceptualization, development, and writing of research proposals in epidemiology and other forms of clinical field research.

EPI950.name: Advanced Biostatistical Methods in Epidemiology
EPI950.description: Study of specific biostatistical methods and epidemiology applications.
EPI950.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI952.name: Duration and Severity Analysis
EPI952.description: Analysis of data that involve time to occurrence of a single event or multiple durations between occurrences of several events; modeling techniques; survival analysis in clinical and public health studies; frailty models; experimental and non-experimental applications using major statistical software.
EPI952.prerequisite: (EPI 826B or concurrently) or EPI 826 or approval of department
EPI952.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI953.name: Analytical Strategies for Observational Studies
EPI953.description: Models and methods such as propensity scores, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity design, discrete choice analysis, and marginal structural models. Examples will be demonstrated with procedures in major statistical software.
EPI953.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI977.name: Social Epidemiology
EPI977.description: Introduction to the field of social epidemiology and the social determinants of health. Contemporary theoretical and methodological issues in social epidemiology.
EPI977.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI979.name: Advanced Topics in Infectious Disease Epidemiology
EPI979.description: Epidemiological and public health perspectives on the etiology, transmission and prevention of infectious diseases. Key conceptual and methodological issues associated with studying infectious diseases from molecular and population based perspectives.
EPI979.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

EPI990.name: Independent Study
EPI990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EPI990.description: Special projects, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual graduate student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.
EPI990.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Epidemiology Major. Approval of department.

EPI999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
EPI999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
EPI999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Epidemiology major.
